item.description: By Steve Endow A simple Dynamics GP customer query unexpectedly returned zero results, even though the customer existed in the system. Upon closer inspection, it was discovered that the customer ID had a leading space. While Dynamics GP prevents users from entering leading spaces directly, eConnect allows them during import. This discrepancy can cause issues when querying data, as SQL differentiates between values with and without leading spaces. This highlights the importance of trimming leading and trailing white space from data during integration.

item.title: The free sample has now increased in size by seven times.
item.description: Dateline: 24 January 2017 The initial free sample of the “Minibeds-on-Plastic Report #1” has been expanded. Instead of just the introduction, cover, and contents page, it now includes seven pages in total. This larger sample provides a better overview of the report’s content. You can find more information and a free order button at this link: http://minibedsonplastic.blogspot.com/2017/01/blank-15.html. Thank you to everyone for the feedback. :-)

item.title: T1 Lines to Support Enterprise VoIP
item.description: T1 lines are commonly known for their ability to combine multiple phone calls onto a single line using Time Division Multiplexing (TDM). However, they can also be used for Voice over IP (VoIP) communication between company locations or to connect with the Public Switched Telephone Network (PSTN) through gateways. Traditional T1 lines were designed to carry 24 simultaneous high-quality phone calls over a copper wire pair. Each call is digitized and placed into one of 24 eight-bit time slots, synchronized precisely using atomic clocks.

item.title: Generalized MPLS Improves Optical Networks
item.description: Multi-Protocol Label Switching (MPLS) is a technology that accelerates network speeds and supports various protocols, including IP, ATM, Frame Relay, and SONET. It achieves this by encapsulating these protocols within its own tunnels upon entering the network and restoring them to their original format upon exit. Within the MPLS network, routing occurs based on simplified tags inserted into packet headers. Constructing this specialized network for transporting other network traffic offers the advantage of defining service classes.

item.title: Is it appropriate for the outcome of the European Parliament elections to dictate the selection of the next President of the European Commission, or are there valid concerns about this democratic process?
item.description: It’s doubtful the European Court of Justice will decide the next European Commission President. Election laws typically set the stage but don’t directly determine the winner, although there are notable exceptions like the 2000 US election. The 2014 Commission President election is unique because the rules changed, and their interpretation is debated. Previously, the European Council appointed the President after European Parliament approval. The Treaty of Lisbon introduced new rules, applied for the first time, stating the Parliament “elects” the President based on the Council’s nomination, “taking account” of Parliament election results.

item.title: Vanity Numbers for Small Businesses
item.description: The significance of your business phone number cannot be overstated. It’s your lifeline to customers. If they can’t easily recall your number, they might dial a competitor’s instead. This is where vanity numbers come into play. What exactly are vanity numbers? They are standard phone numbers designed for easy memorization. There are two main categories of vanity numbers. The first type spells a word or phrase, similar to personalized license plates.

item.title: Do You Need a Content Delivery Network?
item.description: The way we deliver content online is evolving rapidly. While you could once manage a website with just a computer and a few phone lines, today’s high-definition video and nationwide audiences demand far more resources. This is where content delivery networks (CDNs) come in. Think of a CDN as a specialized web hosting service. Just as you can host your website on your own server or outsource it, you can also choose between managing your content distribution or relying on a CDN.

item.title: Ethernet Connects Businesses Throughout Latin America
item.description: In recent years, numerous businesses have opted for Carrier Ethernet services for various connectivity needs, including Dedicated Internet Access (DIA), point-to-point private lines, last-mile access to MPLS networks, and meshed connections linking multiple business locations within the United States. This capability is now expanding globally. For instance, Level 3, a prominent international carrier, received recognition from the Metro Ethernet Forum (MEF) for its services in the Caribbean and Latin America.

item.title: The Cyber Resilience Act as it relates to the Internet of Things.
item.description: Mattis van ’t Schip, PhD candidate, Radboud University Image credit: Grafiker61, via Wikicommons Media The Internet of Things (IoT), encompassing devices with integrated hardware and software like smartwatches and WiFi security cameras, is becoming increasingly prevalent in homes and industries. However, the cybersecurity of these connected devices is a growing concern. Hackers have exploited vulnerabilities in these devices, as demonstrated by the Mirai botnet attack, where thousands of devices were compromised to disrupt websites and businesses.

item.title: Why PRI Over T1?
item.description: PRI, or Primary Rate Interface, is a popular digital telephone service used by call centers, PBX systems, and internet providers. It’s part of the ISDN standards. PRI is often referred to as T1 PRI in regions like the USA, Canada, and Japan because it utilizes a T1 carrier trunk. However, there’s also a service simply called T1, making PRI appear as a variation of T1. Traditional T1, known as channelized T1, carries 24 digitized conversations simultaneously using 24 channels of 8 bits each.

item.title: The Deceptive Client: The case that confused the CJEU
item.description: Steve Peers John Grisham’s novels often feature a recurring theme: a determined but outmatched lawyer battling a powerful corporation that exploits the legal system, a vulnerable client harmed by the corporation, a polished corporate law firm doing the company’s bidding, and an eccentric judge striving for courtroom order. This formula has been a mainstay of his books for over two decades. However, the settings rarely venture beyond the Southern United States, except for occasional plot-driven trips to Caribbean islands.

item.title: The complex human rights protection system in Europe: facing challenges, embracing opportunities, and managing risks
item.description: Lecture at Waseda University Tokyo, 14 March 2016 Jörg Polakiewicz Professor at the Europainstitut of the University of Saarbrücken and Director of Legal Advice and Public International Law (Legal Adviser), Council of Europe.[1] Introduction It’s an honor to be presenting at Waseda University in Tokyo. Thank you to Professor Koji Tonami and Professor Kaoru Obata for making this lecture possible. I am consistently impressed by the comprehensive understanding of fundamental rights protection within Japan’s legal system.

item.title: The Year End Update for GP 9 is causing blank sections in the Report Writer when VBA is used.
item.description: A client recently requested changes to their Dynamics GP 9 Purchase Order report. Due to limitations with Report Writer, VBA and RetrieveGlobals9.dll were used to modify the report. Following a recent update (GP 9 2010 YE Payroll Update - KB2435598, version 9.00.0386), the client reported issues with the report printing incorrectly, with edges being cut off. The problem persisted across different workstations and printers. Testing revealed that the issue occurred when printing directly to a printer, but not when printing to screen first.

item.title: Is The End Of Cellular Phone Near?
item.description: Cell phones are essential to modern life, but a recent development calls into question the future of cellular service. The release of the Apple iPad and its allowance of VoIP applications over 3G cellular networks, along with AT&T’s network adjustments for this capability, signal a potential shift in the telecommunications landscape. Why is this significant? Cellular networks have historically blocked VoIP due to its potential to congest networks and cannibalize voice call revenue.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoration of the Arm Lowering Mechanism, Replacement of Tracking Sensor Light Bulb with a LED Assembly, and a New Aluminum Pulley
item.description: My Beogram 4000 arrived damaged from shipping, so I began by fixing it. The carriage, which moves along a rod with bearings, had detached. I took out the rod and bearings to put them back into the carriage correctly. Then, I used a wrench to secure them. This allowed me to reinstall the carriage. Next, I started my usual restoration process, beginning with the arm lowering mechanism. I took apart the solenoid, damper, connecting parts, and springs.

item.title: 1,000,000 Miles of Metro Ethernet Fiber And Growing
item.description: Don’t assume Metro Ethernet is a small, insignificant service. XO Communications alone has a vast network of metro fiber, connecting thousands of buildings. And that’s just one provider, not even counting Ethernet over Copper options. Metro Ethernet and its long-distance counterpart, Carrier Ethernet, are the future of telecommunications. The world is shifting from traditional circuit-based communication to packet-based IP networks. While your current internet might be a T1 line, your data likely transitions to an IP-based backbone at your provider’s location.

item.title: The reason I do not accept foreign checks is due to the complexities of North American banking.
item.description: Years ago, I received a US dollar check from a Canadian Dynamics partner paying their invoice. They used their Canadian bank’s US dollar account, thinking it would simplify things. I assumed a US dollar check for a US dollar invoice would be straightforward. I was wrong. My local Bank of America ATM wouldn’t accept the check. Inside, the teller and even the manager were perplexed. The manager confidently declared they couldn’t accept the check because it was a US dollar check from a Canadian bank.

item.title: Fiber Optic Leased Lines for Business
Comparing Payroll Reconciliation and Tax Flags
item.description: It’s always simpler to reconcile payroll regularly, handling it incrementally rather than tackling large periods at once. Reconciling means performing these steps after each payroll: Print the Check Register: This document, usually generated automatically after posting payroll, details your tax liabilities. Print the Payroll Summary Report: Covering the current quarter up to the payroll check date (accessible via Reports-Payroll-Period End), this report should match your cumulative payroll check registers in terms of wages, taxes, etc.

item.title: Add a Toll Free Number For Next to Nothing
item.description: Upgrading your business phone system can be pricey, but there’s a budget-friendly way to add a toll-free number to any phone, even your cell phone, for a minimal monthly cost. Toll-free numbers are beneficial for businesses with a public phone number. Local customers can call without long-distance charges, but even calls from nearby areas can become expensive. Out-of-state prospects might hesitate to call due to high long-distance rates. Offering a toll-free number encourages calls from anywhere, as the business covers the cost.

item.title: Last Minute Online Gifts For Good
item.description: _On Christmas Eve, instead of the typical peaceful house, your home is filled with stress as you realize you forgot a gift. Despite your best efforts, you overlooked someone on your list. The pressure is on to find a solution quickly. Don’t worry, there’s a solution that can save your holiday! Search online and find the K.I.N.D site for the perfect gift. You’ll not only deliver a thoughtful present but also make a difference.

item.title: Don't waste a valuable opportunity: the importance and methods of reforming the governance of European football following the collapse of the 'SuperLeague'
item.description: Professor Stephen Weatherill, Faculty of Law and Somerville College, University of Oxford, analyzes the attempted formation of a European SuperLeague and what it reveals about the weaknesses in European football governance and legal frameworks. He argues that while the SuperLeague ultimately failed, the desire for such a league persists and requires proactive legal and structural reforms to safeguard the European model of sport. A Persistent Threat The proposed SuperLeague, driven by wealthy and commercially successful clubs, posed a significant challenge to UEFA, the governing body of European football.

item.title: Xperience the Sony Ericsson Xperia X10
item.description: The Xperia X10 might be the perfect smartphone you’ve been looking for. It boasts an 8.1 Megapixel camera and a 4-inch touchscreen, which begs the question: do you really need to carry a separate camera? The Xperia’s camera eliminates that need with features like flash, 16x zoom, touch focus, geo-tagging, smile detection, and a ‘send to web’ option. It’s adaptable for landscape, portrait, night, beach, and various other settings. You can even edit photos directly on the phone using apps from the Android Market.

item.title: VPLS Is The Ethernet Cloud
item.description: We’re all familiar with cloud networks, but wouldn’t it be great to have a private cloud connecting all your business locations? Virtual Private LAN Service (VPLS) offers a solution. While not a fully private cloud, it comes close. VPLS allows you to share a private multipoint network built on technology like Multi-Protocol Label Switching (MPLS). MPLS networks can handle various traffic types, including Ethernet, making it ideal for diverse needs.

item.title: ATM Networks: Little Cells Doing Big Things
item.description: While the ATM acronym might make you think of cash machines, in the networking world, it stands for Asynchronous Transfer Mode. This core transmission protocol, unlike its namesake, isn’t something most consumers encounter directly. ATM is a technology that falls into the same family as Ethernet, Frame Relay, and TDM. Although once considered a potential universal networking solution, it didn’t achieve that status. Nonetheless, a significant portion of telecom providers, around 80%, currently utilize ATM within their networks.

item.title: Cheaper DS3 Connections
item.description: Your business needs more bandwidth, but the price of a DS3 connection might seem daunting. While upgrading from a T1 line to a DS3 might have seemed expensive in the past, prices have gone down. Even with the current economic climate, a DS3 connection could now be within your budget. DS3, or Data Service level 3, is a digital telecommunications standard initially designed for telephone systems. It’s part of the T-Carrier system and works seamlessly with SONET fiber optic networks.

item.title: Cheap Business Continuity Insurance
item.description: What happens when your business can’t operate? It’s a disaster, leading to lost sales and potentially losing valuable customers. If customers go elsewhere during downtime, they may never return, putting your business at risk. While numerous risks can disrupt your business, connectivity is one you can control. Most businesses, even traditional brick-and-mortar ones, rely heavily on electronic connections like phones and the internet to operate. Losing these vital connections can be devastating.

item.title: VoIP Phone Service Provides Flexibility
item.description: Businesses of all sizes might be considering upgrading their phone systems but are unsure of the best approach. Should they stick with their existing Key Telephone or PBX system and upgrade it, or is it time to transition to VoIP? What many businesses may not realize is the wide range of options that VoIP solutions offer. The key difference between VoIP and traditional phone systems lies in its network-based approach. While even a single-line phone or cell phone operates on a network, known as the Public Switched Telephone Network (PSTN), this network has limitations.

item.title: The extent of the 'household exception' to EU data protection law: Is it like Big Brother's Little Brother?
item.description: Professor Lorna Woods, co-author of “EU Law” by Steiner and Woods, examines a case about data protection and CCTV use. Introduction The Czech Supreme Administrative Court referred a question to the Court of Justice regarding the “household activity” exception in the EU Data Protection Directive. This case, Ryneš, involved CCTV footage capturing images beyond the operator’s property, raising questions about the exception’s scope, especially since the Directive states data processing must be “exclusively” for personal and household purposes.

item.title: There is an issue with sending PDF reports via email using GP 2010 and Office 2010.
item.description: During a recent Electronic Funds Transfer setup for a client, I encountered an error in Microsoft Dynamics GP 2010 R2 while trying to email remittance documents as PDFs. The error message, “You must have the Microsoft Save as PDF or XPS Add-in for 2007 Microsoft Office installed to send documents,” persisted even with Office 2010 (32-bit) installed. This error, encountered by others as well, hinted at a problem with GP’s ability to convert and email reports as PDFs.

item.title: Cellular Netbooks Are Downright Cheap
item.description: Do you spend most of your computing time on the go? If so, a computer designed for mobility might be perfect for you, like one of the new netbooks with built-in 3G cellular internet access. You might be thinking laptops aren’t that bulky and work fine at a coffee shop. That’s true. A laptop with a wireless modem aircard would be comparable to a netbook in functionality. However, laptops are heavier and often carry unnecessary extras.

item.title: Is the European Arrest Warrant compatible with human rights? Can individuals be legally detained for more than 90 days before being surrendered?
item.description: Joske Graat, PhD student, Utrecht University The Amsterdam District Court, solely responsible for handling European Arrest Warrants (EAWs) in the Netherlands, faces a conflict between national and EU laws regarding detention and release. Dutch law mandates the release of a requested individual after 90 days if the court hasn’t made a decision on the EAW. However, a 2015 European Court of Justice (CJEU) ruling stated that national courts can extend detention beyond 90 days to ensure conditions for surrender are met.

item.title: The garden right before the snowstorm.
item.description: Dateline: 21 November 2016 (click on picture for larger view) November in New York’s Finger Lakes region has been delightfully mild. I even took this photo of my garden from the roof two days ago. The tarp in the foreground is full of shredded leaves ready to be spread. The leaves will act as mulch for the winter. You can see several raised beds on the garden’s right side with oats and mustard cover crops.

item.title: Evaluation of the updated EU Council Guidelines on Freedom of Expression in both digital and physical spaces.
item.description: Professor Lorna Woods from the University of Essex, and co-author of Steiner and Woods, EU Law, discusses new EU guidelines on freedom of expression. The European Union Council recently established guidelines for freedom of expression. These guidelines, falling under the Foreign Affairs Council, are designed for application within the framework of the Union’s Common Foreign and Security Policy, similar to previous guidelines addressing issues like torture, capital punishment, and human rights advocates.

item.title: Exploring Carpenter's Falls
item.description: Published on: 28 March 2017 A recent conversation about knots, sparked by my post on un-bungee cords, reminded me of a daring experience from the early 1980s: my first rappelling adventure. At the time, I was working as a carpenter for Clancy Edmonds, who had hired Dan, a machinist, for the summer. Dan, a memorable character who rode a Harley Davidson and carried a .357 magnum, even convinced me to get my handgun permit, arguing it wouldn’t be as easy in the future.

item.title: The European Union should consider the UK police's use of live facial recognition technology when developing regulations for law enforcement.
item.description: Divergent Approaches to Regulating Live Facial Recognition Dr. Asress Adimi Gikay, a Senior Lecturer in AI, Disruptive Innovation, and Law at Brunel University London, explores the contrasting approaches to regulating live facial recognition (LFR) in the UK and the European Union. Recent suggestions by UK officials to use LFR for searching national passport databases to combat shoplifting have sparked debate, particularly as London, a city with a high concentration of CCTV cameras, grapples with AI safety concerns.

item.title: Interview with Eliot Coleman
item.description: Dateline: 9 August 2016 AD Eliot Coleman (photo link) I first discovered Eliot Coleman in the 1970s through an article in Organic Farming & Gardening magazine, which I believe I still have. Now 77 years old, Eliot is considered a leading expert among American organic gardeners. Any serious gardener likely has at least one of Eliot Coleman’s books. By clicking the photo link, you can find twelve gardening books he endorses, in addition to his own works.

item.title: Is the free movement of people in the European Economic Area (EEA) distinct from that in the EU?
item.description: Karin Fløistad: PhD Candidate, European University Institute; practicing lawyer at Norwegian law firm Simonsen Vogt Wiig The UK’s post-Brexit relationship with the EU often involves discussions about the free movement of people, with the EEA Agreement frequently cited as a potential model. This piece will analyze two key distinctions between the EEA Agreement’s approach to the free movement of people and that of full EU membership. The EEA Agreement integrates the EU’s single market with three members of the European Free Trade Association (EFTA): Norway, Iceland, and Liechtenstein.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoring the Hood
item.description: Restoring a Beogram often includes restoring its hood, as many have accumulated scratches over time. This particular Beogram 4002 (5513) had deep scratches on its hood. The restoration started by sanding with 220-grit sandpaper, then progressively moved to finer grits (320-grit shown). This process, which took about 3 hours and involved around 10 polishing steps with Micro-Mesh up to 12000 level, returned the hood to a translucent and shiny condition.

item.title: You Are Definitely Going to Need More Bandwidth
item.description: By: John Shepler Suddenly, the typical workplace is no more. The usual routines of office life have vanished. Employees are no longer commuting to their desks. Cubicles and parking lots are deserted. Countless desktop computers and phones sit idle. The New Normal: Where is Everyone? A small team remains onsite, but the majority of employees are working from home. There’s been a massive effort to establish remote connections using personal computers, iPads, and smartphones, relying on cable and cellular broadband.

item.title: Navigating the legal challenges of the Brexit transition period: A bridge over troubled waters?
item.description: Professor Steve Peers* In a recent speech outlining the UK’s post-Brexit plans, Prime Minister Theresa May’s approach resembled Machiavelli’s strategies more than Leonardo da Vinci’s artistry. Nonetheless, her speech provided a glimpse into the legal structure the UK government envisions for its relationship with the EU during a transitional period after Brexit. While the main points of the Florence speech have been previously discussed, this piece delves deeper into the legal framework and its implications for EU27 citizens in the UK during this transition.

item.title: The CJEU's ruling in C-582/14 Breyer establishes IP addresses as personal data.
item.description: Marcin Kotula, Legal Officer at the European Commission The opinions presented are solely those of the author and should not be interpreted as representing the European Commission’s official stance. Background The Breyer case saw the German Supreme Court (Bundesgerichtshof) request clarification from the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) on whether dynamic IP addresses constitute personal data under the EU Data Protection Directive and to what extent their storage and processing is permissible for maintaining website functionality.

item.title: Build Your Own Private Cloud Storage
item.description: Lots of small and midsize businesses are using cloud storage, particularly for disaster recovery. However, local storage is still necessary. While Storage Attached Networks (SANs) are a common solution, they’re expensive and complex. A simpler option exists. Introducing Drobo, an advanced hard disk storage solution that’s surprisingly easy to use. It works with standard 3.5" SATA drives of any capacity, resembling a straightforward multi-bay drive enclosure. Adding or removing drives, even swapping a 1 TB for a 2 TB, is always possible.

item.title: Migration of General Ledger Balances - Net Change Compared to Debit and Credit
item.description: I was talking with a client yesterday about their General Ledger (GL) balances from before they started using our system in May. They were puzzled by the activity in a particular account from January to March, seeing only a $100 credit in January, a $50 debit in February, and a $200 credit in March. They wondered why each month didn’t show both debits and credits. It took me a moment to realize that, unlike my usual practice of migrating both debit and credit activity for complete GL history, someone else had migrated only the net change for each period from their old system.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Service Manual Adjustments & Preparing for Use
item.description: In the previous post, I finished cleaning and deoxidizing the keypad and RPM panel. The keypad is now responsive, but the cueing up and down button is overly sensitive and needs further attention. The RPM panel re-installation was put on hold because the plastic mounting fixtures were cracked, a common issue with Beogram 4002 turntables. I was fortunate that the cracks weren’t severe and the fixtures were still usable. To repair them, I used acrylic repair fluid while pressing the pieces together.

item.title: Divergence in regulations after Brexit: Copyright law as a preview of future changes.
item.description: Martin Kretschmer, Professor of Intellectual Property Law (CREATe Centre, University of Glasgow) The UK’s departure from the European Union has resulted in the first instance of regulatory divergence. As the UK exits the single market, existing regulations are starting to show cracks. In response to a question from MP Jo Stevens, former Intellectual Property Minister Chris Skidmore indicated the UK would not implement the latest EU Copyright Directive, despite the UK’s prior support for it in the EU Council.

item.title: DIA and VPN For Europe
item.description: Level 3 Communications, a major internet services provider with a global reach, is expanding its Dedicated Internet Access (DIA) and Virtual Private Network (VPN) services into European markets, including France, Germany, and the United Kingdom. The company recognizes the increasing importance of international connectivity for business success in a globalized marketplace. While large corporations often manage their own private networks, many businesses need reliable internet access without the high investment. These businesses require high-quality internet for e-commerce, customer communication, and connecting geographically dispersed locations.

item.title: The CJEU establishes significant limitations on the Commission's power to initiate actions.
item.description: Steve Peers It is a fundamental principle of EU law, as taught to every student of the subject, that the Commission has a near-monopoly on proposing new EU legislation - it is the ‘motor’ of EU integration. This near-monopoly is often called the Commission’s ‘right of initiative’. But does this right also imply a right to withdraw proposals? And if it does, are there any limitations to this power? These questions were addressed by the CJEU in a significant ruling.

item.title: Bandwidth To Support Branch Offices
item.description: Many businesses need multiple locations in a region to stay close to their customers. Connecting these branches seamlessly without breaking the bank is a common challenge. Thankfully, two high-performance networking technologies, Metro Ethernet and MPLS Networks, offer affordable solutions that weren’t available even a decade ago. Carrier Ethernet takes the local networking capabilities of Ethernet and extends them across entire cities. This means easy connection and efficient transmission without needing protocol conversions.

item.title: Please don't end my year...
item.description: Let’s debunk some common misconceptions about year-end closing in Dynamics GP: Myth #1: All adjusting entries must be finalized before closing the General Ledger. This is false. Dynamics GP allows posting to the most recent historical year. After closing 2009, for instance, adjustments can still be made to it, just not to 2008. This requires enabling “allow posting to history” in GL setup and ensuring the fiscal period is open in Fiscal Period Setup.

item.title: Clearing the Dynamics GP User ID field on Terminal Servers
item.description: This article addresses a known issue in Dynamics GP, specifically regarding user ID retention on Terminal Servers. While convenient for single users, this feature can be disruptive in multi-user environments. The issue arises when multiple users log in and out of Dynamics GP on a Terminal Server. The system tends to remember the last user’s ID, forcing subsequent users to manually replace it with their own. This behavior, though seemingly minor, can be perceived as a security concern or simply an annoyance.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Rebuilding the Output Board, Installation of a Grounding Switch and Repair of the Keypad
item.description: My Beogram 4002 (5513) restoration is almost done. Today, I worked on Output PCB #8 and fixed a loose key on the keypad. The Output PCB #8 was initially in this condition: I prefer to replace the output relay as they tend to get stuck with age. Luckily, the relay is the same one used for platter RPM switching, so my custom replacement boards work here as well: These replacement parts are available to anyone interested; feel free to email me.

item.title: Broadband For The Home Office
item.description: Home office users have a lot of choices when it comes to internet bandwidth, from basic residential DSL and cable to professional options like FIOS, Business DSL, T1, or even Carrier Ethernet. Which one is the right fit? Here’s a breakdown of what’s available and what makes sense for home-based work. Residential broadband services are often the best choice for home offices, primarily because they’re the most affordable. These services are usually confined to residential areas.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (Type 5513): Replacement of Carriage Position Sensor Photocell
item.description: Over many years of working with the Beogram 400x, I’ve encountered a wide array of issues, but these turntables never cease to present new challenges. In this instance, a Beogram 4002 exhibited inconsistent behavior when attempting to locate the record’s setdown point after pressing start. This pointed to a potential fault in the carriage position sensor. Initially, I suspected the IR LED, a common culprit in later models like this 5513 Type.

item.title: T1 PRI For Call Centers
item.description: When deciding on phone service for your call center, digital options are essential. While individual analog lines work for small setups, they lack integration capabilities and become costly as you expand beyond a few lines. For call centers with 10-12 lines using traditional PBX systems, digital T1 carrier service is a cost-effective solution. T1 lines offer two configuration options: channelized and PRI (Primary Rate Interface). Channelized T1 provides 24 independent lines suitable for various call types but lacks advanced features like Caller ID.

item.title: The Rose Is On The Bloom
item.description: Bloom Energy recently introduced its “Energy Server” fuel cell, presenting it as a significant step towards greener energy and energy independence. This begs the question: how impactful will this new technology actually be? While it’s early to definitively say, Bloom Energy’s generators could become a vital part of energy production and management, or even revolutionize our relationship with energy entirely. The Bloom Energy Server originated from a NASA project aimed at generating air and fuel from electricity for Mars expeditions.

item.title: My fondest memory from my time at Sterling College in Vermont is from the Dirt Class in 1976.
item.description: Dated: March 18, 2017 Remembering ‘76 and a Class About Dirt Yesterday’s blog post about soil microbes reminded me of my college soil science class back in the fall of 1976. I was attending Sterling College, although at the time it was a far cry from the established institution it is today. Back then, it was a former prep school attempting to reinvent itself, offering a unique one-year program called The Grassroots Project in Vermont - a very ’70s endeavor.

item.title: Dynamics GP OLE Container and Note Files - Part Two
item.description: Mariano recently provided additional insights on the file format Dynamics uses for its OLE Container files in an update to his informative article about OLE Containers. Utilizing a file compression tool, 7-Zip, he was able to partially deconstruct these OLE files, hinting at a promising discovery. Hopefully, he will share his findings on whether he’s successfully deciphered the OLE file format. Regarding GP Notes, my experience suggests limited consistent usage of the GP Note fields and even less utilization of the OLE Container feature for file attachments or embedding content.

item.title: Fiber Optic Ethernet Transport Offers Huge Advantages
item.description: By: John Shepler Data can be moved in many ways. The new top choice is Fiber Optic Ethernet, known as EoF or Ethernet over Fiber, which offers excellent value. What is Fiber Optic Ethernet Transport? When fiber optic lines were first installed, Ethernet wasn’t a factor. The standard was SONET (Synchronous Optical NETworking), designed to carry existing DS1 and DS3 phone calls on fiber. Fiber offered significantly more bandwidth than copper twisted pair, microwave, or coaxial cable.
